section.title: Searching for and opening the original specification of a Test Case or Test Suite
section.para: To find the the original specification of any reused Test Case or Test Suite:

listitem.para: Single-click the Test Case or Test Suite whose specification you want to find.
Right-click on the Test Case or Test Suite and select ”Show specification” from the context-sensitive menu. You can also press »F6« to show the specification.
The originally specified Test Case or Test Suite will be highlighted in the Test Case Browser or Test Suite Browser.

You can open the specified Test Case or Test Suite automatically by selecting ”Open specification” or by pressing »F3«. This also works on the original specification of Test Cases, Test Suites and Test Jobs in the brosers.

If you double-click the Test Case or Test Suite while it is in an editor, then this will also open the original specification (as if you had pressed »F3«).
Test Cases and Test Suites that are not visible due to active filters in the browser are not displayed when show specification is used. You can, however, use open specification to directly open a filtered Test Case or Test Suite.

section.title: Searching for places where a Test Case or Test Suite has been used
section.para: To find the places where you have reused a Test Case or a Test Suite:

listitem.para: In a browser or an editor, right-click on the Test Case or Test Suite whose places of reuse you want to find. You must have selected the parent (original specification) for the action to be enabled.
Select ”show where reused” from the context sensitive menu. You can also press »F7« to show the places where a Test Case or Test Suite has been reused.
In the ”Search Result View” (), a list of places will appear. These are the places where the Test Case or Test Suite has been reused.
Double-click on an icon in the view to highlight and open the place of reuse.

If you are using this option on a Test Case and want to replace the Test Case you searched for with another Test Case at some or all of the places where it is reused, you can start this action from the Search Result View ().

para.para: If you select this option on a nested Test Case, you will be shown the other places where the Test Case is nested. To see where its parent Test Case is used, you must then carry out the same steps on the parent.

section.title: Searching for places where a component name has been used
section.para: You can find the places where you have used a component name from within the Object Mapping Editor and the Component Names Browser.
In the Component Names Browser:

listitem.para:
Select the component name you want to search for and select:
Show where used
from the context-sensitive menu. You can also press »F7« to show the places where the name has been used.
All the places where you have used this component name in this Project will be shown in the Search Result View (). Both Test Cases and object mappings where the component name was used will be shown.

section.para: In the Object Mapping Editor: Show where used:

listitem.para:
Select the component name you want to search for and select:
Show where used
from the context-sensitive menu. You can also press »F7« to show the places where the name has been used.
All the places where you have used this component name in this Project will be shown in the Search Result View ().

section.para: In the Object Mapping Editor: Show corresponding specification: Use this option when a component name appears in the Object Mapping Editor that should have been overwritten, but hasn’t been.

listitem.para:
Select the component name you want to search for and select:
Show corresponding specification
from the context-sensitive menu.
The Search Result View only shows places which could have lead to this component name appearing in the Object Mapping Editor, not all places in the test where it has been used.

section.title: Searching for places where a central test data set has been used
section.para: You can find the places where you have used a central test data set from within the Central Test Data Editor:

listitem.para:
Select the central data set you want to search for and select:
Show where used
from the context-sensitive menu. You can also press »F7« to show the places where the data set has been used.
All the places where you have used this data set in this Project will be shown in the ”Search Result View” ().
If you want to change the Test Cases that use this central test data set so that they use a different column from the data set, then you can start this action from the Search Result View ().

section.title: Using the search dialog
section.para:
You can open the search dialog () from the toolbar, by pressing »CTRL+H« or via the menu:
Search-->Search
The search dialog allows you to search the current Project in the current working language for:

listitem.para: Keywords () (Test Cases, Test Steps, Test Suites, Test Jobs and categories).
Test data used in Test Cases or central test data sets ().
Files in the workspace ().
Tasks in the repository ()

section.title: Searching for keywords throughout the Project
section.para: On the first tab of the search dialog, you can search for the following based on their name, a comment, a description, or a task ID.:

listitem.para: Test Steps
Test Cases – either the original specification or places where a Test Case has been reused (referenced)
Test Suites – either the original specification or places where a Test Suite has been reused (referenced)
Test Jobs
Categories

section.para: Enter the term you wish to search for and select whether you want the search term to be case sensitive or whether you will be using regular expressions. Specify what aspects you want to search the node types for (name, comment, description, task ID) and which nodes you want to search in. You can also specify whether you want to search in the whole Project, or just for the selected nodes ().
Click ”Search” to start the search. The results are shown in the Search Result View ().

para.para: Only results from the current working language are displayed.

section.title: Searching for test data
section.para: On the second tab of the search dialog, you can search for test data in the following:

listitem.para: Central test data sets
Test Cases – either either the original specification or places where a Test Case has been reused (referenced)
Test Steps

para.para: The search does not consider the name of the central test data set, for example, only the data contained in it.

section.para: Enter the term you wish to search for and select whether you want the search term to be case sensitive or whether you will be using regular expressions. You can also specify whether you want to search in the whole Project, or just for the selected nodes ().
Click ”Search” to start the search. The results are shown in the Search Result View ().

para.para: Only test data from the current working language is displayed.

section.title: Searching for files in the workspace
section.para: On the third tab of the search dialog, you can search for and in files contained in your workspace.
Enter the term you wish to search for and click ”Search” to start the search. The results are shown in the Search Result View ().

section.title: Limiting the search to the selected node
section.para: In the search dialog, you can specify whether the search you define should be performed on the whole Project, or just on the node you have selected in a browser. If you select to just search within the selected node, then you can define which browser or browsers to search in (you may have more than one active selection in your browsers):

listitem.para: This search will be limited to the selected item (Test Suite, Test Job, category) in the Test Suite Browser. If you select the root node in the Test Suite Browser, then the whole Test Suite Browser will be searched.

This search will be limited to the selected item (Test Case, category) in the Test Case Browser. If you have more than one Test Case Browser open (), then the one marked as Main will be used. If you select the root node in the Test Case Browser, then the whole Test Case Browser will be searched.

If you have more than one Test Case Browser open (), then the selected nodes in all of them will be searched.If you select the root node in the Test Case Browser, then the whole Test Case Browser will be searched.

section.para: You can select one or more of these options to perform the search.

section.title: Searching for tasks in ALM repositories
section.para: On the fourth tab of the search dialog, you can search for tasks in any repositories you have referenced in the Project.
You can use this search if you have joined your Project to an external respository.
Click ”Search” to start the search. The results are shown in the Search Result View ().

section.title: Using the search result view
section.para: The Search Result View shows any items found during a search – either via the search dialog or the ”Show where used” action.
From the Search Result View, you can:

listitem.para: Double-click on an item to open its editor.
Re-run the search using the button in the top right-hand corner of the view.
Perform various actions on your search results ()

section.title: Using search results to make wide-reaching changes to your Project
section.para: Once you have performed a search, you can perform specific actions on the results:

listitem.para: You can replace a Test Case at multiple places where it has been reused with another Test Case ().
You can change the column of a central test data set used by any Test Cases that use this central test data set ().

section.title: Searching for items in editors and browsers
section.para: The ITE offers a search function in most editors and views.

listitem.para:
Start the search function either via:
Edit-->Find
or using the context-sensitive menu in the editors and browsers.
In the find dialog, you can enter the following criteria:
The text you are searching for.
The direction you want to search in.
Whether the search is case sensitive or not.

Whether you are using regular expressions ().
Regular expression searches are case-sensitive.
Whether the search should be wrapped. This will carry on the search from the top of the browser once you reach the bottom of the browser.
Items which correspond to the search terms are highlighted in gray.

section.title: Text filters
section.para: The Test Case Browser, the Test Suite Browser, the Component Names Browser and the Object Mapping Editor (in the tree view) all contain a filter area at the top. You can enter a filter text into this area to show matches to the text in the browser or editor. Use star (*) as a wildcard.
In the Test Case Browser, the Component Names Browser and the Test Suite Browser, the names of the items in the browser are considered for the filter.
In the Object Mapping Editor, the names and types of the components are considered for the filter.

section.title: Other filter options
section.para: Some browsers offer pre-defined filters in the top right-hand corner.
In the Component Names Browser, you have the following options:

listitem.para: Sort by name or by type
Hide component names from reused Projects.

section.para:
In the Test Case Browser, you can also show any unused Test Cases.
We recommend using this filter to refactor or clear up your test.
